description: From Middle English revēlen, from Old French reveler, from Latin revēlāre (“to reveal, uncover”), from re- (“back, again”) + vēlāre (“to cover”), from vēlum (“veil”).

entries.meaning: The outer side of a window or door frame.
(cinematography, narratology, comedy, usually informal) A revelation; an uncovering of what was hidden in the scene or story.
examples: The comedian had been telling us about his sleep being disturbed by noise. Then came the reveal: he was sleeping on a bed in a department store.

verbs.description: reveal (third-person singular simple present reveals, present participle revealing, simple past and past participle revealed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To uncover; to show and display that which was hidden.
examples: Synonyms: uncover, unfold, unveil; see also Thesaurus:reveal

entries.meaning: (transitive) To communicate that which could not be known or discovered without divine or supernatural instruction.
examples: Synonyms: disclose, divulge; see also Thesaurus:divulge
